attributes.description: What networks flow into and out of your life? A woman sits at her kitchen diner in Chula Vista, San Diego. She looks around, noting the first things upon which her eyes fall. Where did they come from? What stories do they tell? How do they connect her to strangers across the globe? Click on each point and read the story.
attributes.title: Flow #3

attributes.description: The strawberry fields really were vast. 540 acres the man said as they traipsed through the muddy field. Lily lagged behind as the tour around the Manzanita berry farm progressed. She dearly wanted to stamp on one of the fragile plants, squishing the ripe strawberries to a pulp. She was so bored. Her mum had taken her iPod off her, so she couldn’t even drown out the voice of this boring man doing the tour. Who cares how they pick the stupid berries anyway? Maybe if they all looked the other way, she could make a run for the mountains.
attributes.title: Strawberry fields

attributes.description: The corrugated trays were delivered from Robert Mann packaging in the morning. Delicious strawberries rolled into them, filling them. Then they were weighed, the boxes placed on a conveyer belt once their weight was within tolerance. It wasn’t an exciting job, checking none of them were smashed and that people were getting a fair portion in their package. Still, it kept Emilio paid in between gigs, and he had all the strawberries he could eat. Not bad for a starving artist.
attributes.address: 1850 West Stowell Road, Santa Maria, CA 93458, USA
attributes.placename: 1850 West Stowell Road, Santa Maria, CA 93458, USA
attributes.title: Berry boxing

attributes.description: A bright morning in San Diego and the sun had been up for about an hour when the delivery van pulled into the alley behind Whole Foods. Strawberries, in plastic boxes inside cardboard boxes, were the first thing to be unloaded. The team of two stacked box on crate on box on crate on wheels until the pile stood higher than either of them, then pushed it inside through the metal-protected double doors into the shop’s store. Inside, a young guy moved the topmost boxes onto another trolley, and wheeled them out onto the shop floor just as the instore lights blinked on.
attributes.address: 711 University Avenue, Whole Foods Market, San Diego, CA 92103, USA
attributes.placename: 711 University Avenue, Whole Foods Market, San Diego, CA 92103, USA
attributes.title: WholeFoods Market

attributes.description: It was getting to be 2:30 pm. Sarah was a bit peckish after her lunch of half a can of soup and a piece of toast. Stupid diet. Surely a few strawberries wouldn’t hurt. She went to the fridge and pulled out a punnet. For a moment she wrestled with the lid - she didn’t like this awkward packaging, it was much more fun when they went and picked their own in little cardboard punnets like when she’d been a kid. The package popped open, but Sarah fumbled and the strawberries cascaded onto the floor. “Well, they’re all bruised now,” she said to herself. “They won’t last. May as well just eat them.”
attributes.title: Sarah's fridge
